botanical_details.genus: Pelargonium can be perennials, sub-shrubs or shrubs, sometimes succulent and mostly evergreen, with palmately lobed or pinnately divided leaves and clusters of slightly irregular, 5-petalled flowers
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Zonal pelargoniums are bushy evergreen perennials with fleshy stems, rounded, palmately lobed leaves often zoned with maroon, and single or double flowers in shades of purple, red, pink, orange and white, from early to late summer

how_to_grow.cultivation: Under glass grow in a loam-less or loam-based potting compost in full light with shade from hot sun with good ventilation. When in growth water moderately and apply a balanced liquid fertiliser in spring and early summer. A high potash fertiliser should be used when in flower. Water sparingly in winter. Can be grown outside in frost-free areas in a fertile soil. Further pelargonium cultivation advice
how_to_grow.pests: Vine weevil, leafhoppers, caterpillars, thrips, fungus gnats and aphids can be troublesome
how_to_grow.diseases: May be subject to grey moulds when grown under glass. Pelargonium rust and a virus may affect plants
